claim: If A was born before B, then A is older than B

supporting.text: By definition, being born earlier means having existed for a longer period of time, making A older than B.

attacks.text: By definition, being born earlier means having existed for a longer period of time, making A older than B.
If A was born before B but died before B was born, then A never coexisted with B and thus cannot be compared in age at any point in time.
Age comparison is typically based on birth dates, not coexistence, so A's earlier birth still makes them older than B regardless of lifespan overlap.
In relativistic scenarios (e.g., space travel at near-light speeds), A's earlier birth may not correspond to experiencing more time than B due to time dilation.
Relativistic effects are negligible for everyday age comparisons, so the original definition remains practically valid in normal circumstances.

supporting.text: Age is determined by the time elapsed since birth, so if A was born before B, A has a greater age.

attacks.text: Age is determined by the time elapsed since birth, so if A was born before B, A has a greater age.
If A was born before B but died before B's birth, then A is not older than B at any point in time.
In common usage, 'older than' refers to current age, not historical comparisons, so A being born before B still makes A older than B in most contexts.
If A and B are born in different time zones or calendars, the exact birth order may be ambiguous, complicating age comparison.
Standardized timekeeping (e.g., UTC) resolves time zone ambiguities, making birth order objectively determinable in practice.

supporting.text: In all legal and social contexts, the person born first is considered the older individual.

attacks.text: In all legal and social contexts, the person born first is considered the older individual.
In cases of time zone differences, a person born earlier in a later time zone may have a later birth date in universal time.
Legal systems typically standardize birth records to a single time zone or UTC to resolve such ambiguities.
In rare cases of intersex or ambiguous birth records, the order of birth may not be clearly established.
Legal frameworks have procedures to establish official birth order even in ambiguous cases.

supporting.text: Chronological age is universally calculated from birth date, so an earlier birth date results in higher age.

attacks.text: Chronological age is universally calculated from birth date, so an earlier birth date results in higher age.
In some cultures, age is calculated differently, such as counting time in the womb or resetting age at the Lunar New Year.
Even in cultures with alternative age-counting methods, chronological age based on birth date remains the standard for legal and scientific purposes.
Time zones and international date lines can create edge cases where a person born earlier in one time zone may have a later birth date in another.
Legal systems resolve time zone discrepancies by using a standardized reference (e.g., UTC) for birth records, eliminating ambiguity.
